intro: Camelina transcaspica, commonly known as the Transcaspian camelina, is an annual herb native to Central Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many economically important oilseed crops. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with simple, alternate leaves that are lanceolate in shape. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. The seeds are encased in a capsule and are rich in oil, making the plant potentially valuable for agricultural and industrial applications.
